loans.name: Komang Ngurah

texts.en: Komang Ngurah W. K., 34, lives with his wife and one of his children, who is five years old. His main job is as a motorcycle salesman. Currently, he has a new side job as a distributor of soy milk in a box. Soy milk sells very successful in the market. He needs additional funds to enlarge the business capital of his soy milk business. He will use the loan to buy 50 boxes of soy milk.  One box contains 24 pieces of small boxes. The prise of one box is Rp. 36,000, which he sells at Rp. 40,000. For every box, he makes a profit of Rp. 4,000.  When he does direct selling to customers, he sells pieces for Rp. 2.000 so that he gets a profit of Rp. 12,000 per box. He hopes these efforts will grow so that he can serve more customers.

loans.use: to buy 50 boxes of soy milk

loans.name: Kea

texts.en:
Kea U., 43, is married and resides with her husband in Takeo province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. U. sells silk products, earning an income of USD 4 per day. Her husband is a farmer and construction worker, earning an income of USD 3 per day to help cover the family expenses. Each month, the family spends USD 42 on food and USD 35 on the other necessary expenses.

U. is requesting a loan of USD 600 to purchase more cows to raise for sale. In the future, she would like to use the additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long standing Kiva partner. U. appears in the photograph with her husband.

loans.use: to buy cows to raise for sale

loans.name: Chroeng

texts.en: Chroeng K. is a 50-year-old rice farmer who lives in the capital, Phnom Penh. She doesn’t have a life partner because her husband died of senility, many years ago. Chroeng K. is blessed with four children who are no longer in school. To help support the family’s needs, two of her kids work in construction, while another one is employed in a garment factory. Chroeng K. has a plot of farmland, located away from the watering system. For this reason, she cannot irrigate her crops easily. In order to deal with this problem, Chroeng K. is requesting for a loan to purchase a machine that she can use to pump the water for her crops. She will also buy a few sacks of fertilizer for her crop to grow well. She hopes to use the remainder of the funds to buy a sewing machine for her daughter.

loans.use: To purchase a pumping machine and a few sacks of fertilizers for her crop growing well.

loans.name: Sainbuyan

texts.en: Sainbuyan is a 23-year-old single man who lives with his mother and brother in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. His younger brother is a university student and Sainbuyan helps him pay his tuition fees. Sainbuyan’s family rents a 3-hectare plot of land 100 km from the capital city, which they use to plant vegetables such as potatoes, carrots, cabbages, turnips, onions, etc. Sainbuyan uses part of the land to grow his own vegetables. He said that he inherited the skill from his mother. In early spring, he sows the seeds and looks after the growth process during the summer. Sainbuyan’s mother helps him sell the vegetables in the vegetable market in Ulaanbaatar. This year Sainbuyan is planning to increase his harvest and income based on last year's experience. The loan Sainbuyan is requesting will be used to buy more vegetable seeds and organic fertilizers.

loans.use: to buy more vegetable seeds to increase his harvest this year.

loans.name: Ni Putu

texts.en:
Ni Putu S. has a pig farming business to support her family's economy. Her husband works as a farmer. She requires a loan of Rp. 2,000,000 to purchase a sow. A sow can give birth to as many as 10 piglets. After taking care of them for 3-4 months, the piglets are ready for sale at a price of Rp. 350,000 per piglet, giving a profit of Rp.100,000 after deducting expenses incurred.

Ni Putu S. has a dream of renovating her house, which is still very small. She wants to add a room behind her house that will be used for a kitchen.

loans.use: to purchase a sow

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes is a married woman who lives in Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating pig fattening and sari-sari store businesses. Her husband Manuelito, who is 44 years old, works as a laborer to earn his living and helps in his wife's business activities. They have three children who are between 11 and 20 years old.

Agnes joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1997 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 19 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Agnes has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 17,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 10,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 20th loan, she is borrowing PHP 17,000 to purchase  more feed and vitamins for her pig fattening business so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children. Agnes is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.use: to purchase more vitamins and feed for the pigs

loans.name: 52 Quảng Hưng Group

texts.en:
Duyên N. Thị (82) is a 37-year-old woman living in the town of Thanh Hoá. Duyên is the group leader of a 3-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 52 Quảng Hưng (18.02.52 Quảng Hưng).

Duyên is married and has 2 school-aged children. She owns and operates a food stall, selling seafood products such as fish and shrimp in the local community. Duyên has been engaged in this business for over 5 years and earns approximately 2,100,000 VND a month from it.

In 2009, Duyên joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Duyên has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,079,800 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women, which was used to purchase additional products to sell. She is now requesting a new loan of 6,000,000 VND which will be used to purchase fishes, shrimps...to resell. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Duyên from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

About the other borrowers in the group:

1.  N. Thị Hiền (84) is a 49-year-old woman who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her business raising livestock.


2.  H. Thị Hợp (85) is a 48-year-old woman who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her business making and selling food.


About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of the Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainable financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


Duyên N. Thị (82) là 37 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Thanh Hoá.  Duyên là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 3 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 52 Quảng Hưng (18.02.52 Quảng Hưng).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ bán hải sản như cá và tôm trong cộng đồng địa phương.  Duyên thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 5 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Duyên kiếm được khoảng 2,100,000 VND.  Vào 2009, Duyên đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Duyên đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 3,079,800 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua các sản phẩm bổ sung để bán.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 6,000,000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 3rd khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  N. Thị Hiền (84) là 49 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6,000,000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


2.  H. Thị Hợp (85) là 48 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6,000,000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn.


Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."

loans.use: to purchase fish and shrip to sell.

loans.name: Johaima

texts.en: Johaima is a 33-year-old widow who supports her family with fishing and fish vending businesses.  She lives in Rizal, Palawan. Johaima joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past four loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Johaima has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 7,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 10,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her fifth loan, she is borrowing PHP 10,000 to buy fishing gear and equipment so that she can continue to save up for future business expansion and house repairs. Johaima is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.use: to purchase fishing gear and equipment

loans.name: Loh

texts.en: Loh D., age 54, is a businesswoman who earns a living by selling different kinds of seafoods in the busy market. She and her husband have been in the sector since 2005. They always get up early in the morning in order to go to the rural areas to buy seafood in bulk from wholesale suppliers. Then, they hurry up to bring their goods to sell for a profit. Usually, the couple could make a profit from this business about $14 each day to ensure their family living in the simple life. They have four children, all of whom are studying in school. Currently, this family has lived in an old house, which is too old. Some parts of their house are broken. Loh D. has decided to ask for a loan from Kiva to repair her broken house.

loans.use: to repair her broken house.

loans.name: Jugie

texts.en:
Jugie is a married woman who lives in the island of Cebu. She earns her living by selling fruits and vegetables and operating a pig fattening business. Her husband Joel, who is 32 years old, works as a driver to earn his living and helps in his wife's business activities.  They have five children who are between 1 and 7 years old.

Jugie joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past four loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Jugie has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 10,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 6,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her fifth loan, she is borrowing PHP 11,000, which she intends to use to purchase fruits and vegetables so that she can continue to save up for the future needs of the family. Jugie is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.use: to purchase vegetables and fruits to sell

loans.name: Armelita

texts.en:
Armelita is a married woman who lives in the island of Palawan. She earns her living by operating a palm oil farm and a sand & gravel quarry. Her husband Renato, who is 47 years old, works as a farmer to earn his living and helps in his wife's business activities.  They have two children who are 28 and 29 years old. 

Armelita joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2005 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 18 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Armelita has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 29,500 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 20,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 19th loan, she is borrowing PHP 29,500 to fund her palm oil farming operation so that she can continue to save up for the future expansion of her business. Armelita is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.use: To fund her palm oil farming

loans.name: Safari Indah Group

texts.en: Ni Nyoman S., is a farmer and housewife. Ni Nyoman S. has a pig business in an effort to support her family's economy.  Ni Nyoman S. got a loan of Rp. 1.5 million for the second time from MUK Rp. The loan will be used to buy four pigs. Currently, she already has two pigs, so she will own a total of six pigs. From the sale of pigs, Ni Nyoman S. has plans to save the profits because she has plans to renovate her home. She has a dream that a house she owns would be a comfortable home to live in with the whole family.

loans.use: to buy four pigs

loans.name: Jermelyn

texts.en:
Jermelyn is a married woman who lives in Palawan. She earns her living by operating a general store and a livestock business. Her husband Jesus, who is 55 years old, works as a prison guard to earn his living.  They have three children who are between 18 and 25 years old. 

Jermelyn  joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2009 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Jermelyn has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 25,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 18,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her sixth loan, she is borrowing PHP 25,000 to pay for more goods to sell so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children and expansion of her business. Jermelyn is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.use: to purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Ket

texts.en:
From the province of Kompong Cham, Ket S. has been in the farming business for years. She has been planting various crops to earn a living and typically generates an income of $1 per day. Her husband is a recycling seller. He buys used goods to sell to a wholesaler, who then sells the goods in bulk to other countries for a daily income. The used goods he deals in are mostly electrical wires, cans, bottles and plastic. 

Ket S.’s husband uses an old bicycle as a vehicle to pick up his used goods. He's concerned that it is so hard for him to travel far away. To solve this issue, Ket S. is looking for a loan to buy a used motorcycle in order to make her husband's transportation easier.

loans.use: To buy a used motorcycle in order to make her husband's transportation easier

loans.name: Erdenetsetseg

texts.en: Mrs. Erdenetsetseg, 46 years old, lives with her husband and son in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her eldest son just graduated from Railway College and lives separately. Her youngest son is studying in college. Erdenetsetseg is a taxi driver. She has been running a taxi business since 2001 using her family car. She transports people between Ulaanbaatar and Khandgait, a residential town located 25 km to the north. Erdenetsetseg is a very nice and sociable person who is working to provide her family with necessary income. A few years ago, she built a house for her family. The house now needs some repairs and renovation. Mrs. Erdenetsetseg is requesting a loan to buy the necessary building materials and to repair the house.

loans.use: to buy building materials and repair her house

loans.name: Satya Laksana Group

texts.en: Ni Ketut S. and all members of the group, Satya Laksana, got a third loan from MUK. The group still wants to join MUK until they can support their own capital for their pig businesses. Ni Ketut S. is a tenacious housewife. Even though she is now 63 years old, she still keeps the spirit to be a hardworking woman. Ni Ketut S. maintains two sows. A new one was purchased after getting the loan, at a price of Rp. 1,300,000, Ni Ketut S. and her husband hope to get more benefits after taking care of the sow. Every day she spends Rp. 10,000 for the kitchen and Rp. 200,000 for electricity and water.

loans.use: To buy a sow

loans.name: Margie

texts.en: Margie is a married woman who lives in Narra, Palawan. She earns her living by operating a general store, raising hogs and farming. Her husband William, who is 28 years old, works as a farmer to earn his living and helps in his wife's business activities. Margie joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 21 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Margie has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 29,500 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 20,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 22nd loan, she is borrowing PHP 29,500 to buy more stock for her general store and as working capital for her other businesses so that she can continue to save up for the future expansion of her business. Margie is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.use: to purchase more stock for her general store

loans.name: Cristy

texts.en: Cristy is a 33-year-old married woman who supports her family by fishing and buying and selling frozen foods.  She lives in Aborlan, Palawan. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2005 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her fishing and frozen foods businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 8,000. Cristy is borrowing PHP 16,000 to purchase fishing supplies. This will be her 11th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 11,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Cristy aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way.

loans.use: to purchase fishing supplies

loans.name: Analyn

texts.en: Analyn is a married woman who lives in Bogo, Cebu. She earns her living by operating a general store. Her husband Jay, who is 35 years old, works as a painter to earn his living and helps in his wife's business activities.  They have four children who are between 7 and 14 years old. Analyn joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2009 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past four loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Analyn has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 6,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 8,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her fifth loan, she is borrowing PHP 10,000 to buy stock for her sari-sari (general) store so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children. Analyn is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.use: to purchase more stock for her store

loans.name: Seng

texts.en:
Seng T. is a 31-year-old mother. She was blessed with only one kid, who is attending the public school. Seng T. is a local farmer, and she has been spending most of her life in the farming business. Seng T. inherited from her grandmother the farmland where she grows different kinds of crops.

Her husband, Lim Gnor, is 30 and earns a profit as a recycling seller in and around his community, Kompong Cham province. He buys used goods to sell to his regular wholesaler, who sells the items in bulk to other countries. The used goods he sells are mostly leftover electricity wires. 

Seng T. would like to use her loan to buy a secondhand motorbike for her husband to pick up his used goods from far away.

loans.use: To buy a secondhand motorbike for her husband to pick up his used goods

loans.name: Lolie

texts.en:
Lolie is a 45-year old married woman who supports her family by operating a rice mill, buying and selling copra (dried coconut milk) and farming. She lives in Narra, Palawan. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2004 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 25,000. 

Lolie is borrowing PHP 29,500 so that she can pay for the laborers' salaries and other expenses in the rice mill.  This will be her 21st loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 29,500, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Lolie aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way.

loans.use: to pay for laborers' salaries and other expenses in the rice mill

loans.name: Marissa

texts.en:
Marissa P. is from the village of Del Pilar, Cabatuan, Isabela. She is 46 years old, married and has 2 adult-aged children. Marissa owns and operates a general store, primarily selling children's products such as toys and games in the local community. Marissa has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2011, Marissa joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marissa is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and to increase working capital. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Marissa from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory

loans.name: Oliver

texts.en:
Oliver G. is 56 years old, married and has five adult-aged children. He is from the village of Villa Victoria in Echague barangay, a part of Isabela province on the Luzon islands. Oliver is a farmer who plants and harvests rice for sale. Oliver has been in business for over thirty years and earns approximately 25,000 PHP every harvest season.

In 2010, Oliver joined ASKI to gain access to its financial services. He is requesting a new loan, his second from ASKI, of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve his farm.

About ASKI:

Alalay sa Kaunlaran, Inc., or ASKI, is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishermen and -women, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that one-on-one translations of entrepreneur profiles are costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow it to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops

loans.name: Berawan Salak Permai Group

texts.en: Ni Kadek R. A., 24 years old, has a baby son. Her husband works as a brick maker. Aside from being a farmer to support her family, she runs a pig farming business. Through the programs offered by MUK, she joined the group Berawan Salak Permai and was appointed as Chairman. The loan will be used to purchase three piglets and pig feed. Currently, she already has a good barn and two types of local pigs. Within six months, she hopes her efforts will go well, without any disease or other constraints.

loans.use: to purchase three piglets and pig feed

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria G. is 58 years old, married and has three adult-aged children. She is from the village of Del Pilar in Cabatuan, Isabela. Maria is a Filipino lives in the Philippines. She runs a general store from which she sells both food and daily use products to the local community. Maria has been in business for over five years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP a month.

In 2006, Maria joined ASKI to gain access to its financial services. She successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI which was used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. Maria is requesting a new loan, her sixth from ASKI, of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell such as canned goods, sugar, coffee and soap. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell such as canned goods, sugar, coffee and soap

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Yom

texts.en:
Yom K. has been spending her life cultivating crops on her own farmland in Kompong Cham province. She had learned this skill from her grandparent when she was single. She is now married and has two school-aged kids. 

She has the another financial earner in her husband who is currently a recycling seller. He always goes to buy used goods from the people who live in his village and other villages. The used goods he buys mostly come from cans, plastics and electronic wires, which he then sells to his wholesalers for a profit. 

Her husband always picks up the items by using his old motorbike. Unfortunately, the existing motorbike often breaks down during use. Because of that, Yom K. has decided to seek a loan of $400 from Kiva, which she will use to change the broken motorcycle for her husband. 

Note that Yom K. and her husband appear in the picture.

loans.use: To change her husband's broken motorcycle

loans.name: Davaasuren

texts.en:
Mrs. Davaasuren B. is 29 years old and lives with her husband and two children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. They live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Davaasuren’s husband used to run a taxi business using his family’s car, but currently he is at home because he sold the car and is trying to replace it.

Davaasuren operates a public toilet on the Intercity bus station, which she rents from the local council. Her business is doing well and it is the only source of family income at the moment.

Davaasuren has applied for a loan to replace the old fences around the ger in which they live.

loans.use: to buy wooden planks to replace the old fences around her ger

loans.name: Emelito

texts.en:
Emelito M. is from the village of Villa Victoria Echague, Isabela. He is 36 years old. Emelito is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Emelito owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Emelito has been engaged in his business for over 8 years and earns approximately 20,000 PHP per harvest.

In 2011, Emelito joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Emelito is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Emelito from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise.

loans.name: Gnien

texts.en: Gnien S. is a 51-year-old married woman and a local villager living in a medium-sized home with family members in Kompong Cham Province. She owns a piece of farmland that she inherited many years ago from her grandparents. She uses this land to plants rice crops. Her husband is a carpenter who is good at building wooden houses. He earns a profit of approximately $1.50 a day to share responsibility with Gnien S. for the entire family’s expenses. Gnien S. is looking for a loan to buy fertilizers and purchase an ox because her old ox can't support her farm work.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and purchase an ox because her old ox can't support her farm work.

loans.name: Batbold

texts.en:
Mr. Batbold is a 31 year old taxi driver. He lives with his wife and two sons in Kherlen soum of Dornot aimag, the far eastern province of Mongolia, which is 700 kms away from the capital city.

He has been running a taxi business since 2006 and it is the only source of income for the family at the moment. His wife looks after the youngest son who is 4 months old. Batbold is planning to increase his family’s income by renting a stall at the local outdoor market and selling clothes, which he will buy from wholesalers. Batbold’s wife Oyuntuya is going to operate the stall. While Oyuntuya is at the market, her mother is going to look after the kids.
The loan Mr. Batbold is taking will be used to pay for the first installment of stall rent and to buy clothes to sell from wholesalers.

loans.use: to pay for first installment of stall rent and to buy clothes to sell from wholesalers.

loans.name: Pheng

texts.en:
Pheng K. is a 53-year-old farmer who lives in Prey Chhor district, Kompong Cham. Pheng K. is married to Horng Va, age 54. Her husband is a chief villager as well as a local farmer. 

This couple always work together in the farming business. They have five children: two of the children are married three are single. Recently, the family's living conditions have not been comfortable because their toilet is surrounded by pollutants, which is harmful to their health. Therefore, Pheng K. is requesting a loan to build a restroom for her family's sanitation, and to dig a well.

loans.use: To build a restroom for her family's sanitation, and to dig a well.

loans.name: Yim

texts.en: The woman shown in the picture is Yim S., 23, a fisherman who lives in the province of Siem Reap. She and her husband usually spend eight hours a day fishing, in and around Tunle Sap River. They catch around 5 kilos of fish per day and sell them, in bulk, to his customers who are retail sellers in the market. The young couple is blessed with two young children who are not yet enrolled in school. Yim S. will use her loan to purchase nets, traps, and other fishing implements for the fishing business.

loans.use: To purchase nets, traps, and other fishing implements for fishing.

loans.name: Francisca

texts.en:
Francisca is married to a businessman with one child who attends school. They own a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is household goods.

For over ten years, she has operated a food stall business, selling food at the company to workers in the company. Francisca faces a major challenge of delayed payments by creditors. With the loan she is requesting she wants to purchase food stock of maize flour, wheat flour and sugar. She joined Yehu Microfinance to access loans and develop her business.

loans.use: to purchase food stock of maize flour, wheat flour and sugar.

loans.name: Saumu

texts.en:
Saumu is married to a businessman with seven children, three are in school and four have graduated from school. They own a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. For the past 25 years, she has operated a food stall selling business at a nearby school, selling to children going to school. Saumu faces a major challenge of seasonality. There is a high demand during school days and it is low during the holiday season. 

Saumu dreams of expanding her business to generate more income and educate her children. With the Kshs 10,000 she is requesting, she wants to pay school fees for her child. She decided to work with Yehu to access loans to improve her living standards.

loans.use: to pay school fees for her child.

loans.name: Avelina

texts.en:
Avelina is a married woman who lives in the island of Cebu. She earns her living by buying and selling herbal products.  Her husband Vicente, who is 57 years old, works as a driver to earn his living.  They have three children who are between 21 and 33 years old. 

Avelina joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past four loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Avelina has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 9,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 6800, uplifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her fifth loan, she is borrowing PHP 12,000 to buy herbal products to sell to customers so that she can continue to save up for future family needs. Avelina is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.use: to purchase herbal products to sell

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam is married to a businessman with one child who attends school. They own a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

She has operated a food vending business for the past three years, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. Mariam dreams of establishing a café in the future. With the Kshs 20,000 she is requesting, she wants to purchase utensils, plates, water jugs, glasses and Kenya ceramic Jiko. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to modify her business.

loans.use: to purchase utensils, plates, water jugs, glasses and Kenya ceramic Jiko.

loans.name: Said

texts.en:
Said is a married man with three children, all of whom attend school. He owns a house that has electricity but no piped water. His greatest monthly expenses are food and transportation. 

Said has operated a retail shop for the past six years, selling from home to his neighbors and passersby. The business has helped him meet his family's basic needs on a daily basis. Said is planning to use this loan to purchase stock, bundles of wheat and maize flour, and cooking oil. Said decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business to meet customer needs.

loans.use: to purchase inventory, wheat flour, maize flour and cooking oil.

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en: Mercy is a married woman who lives in Toledo City, Cebu. She earns her living by operating a general store and buying & selling scrap. She has five children who are between 12 and 15 years old. Mercy joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2005 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past eight loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Mercy has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 13,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 6,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her ninth loan, she is borrowing PHP 15,000 to buy stock for the store and additional capital to buy and sell scrap so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children. Mercy is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.use: to purchase stock for her general store

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Regina

texts.en:
Regina is married and has one child. She has operated a business selling clothes from home and door-to-door to her neighbors and passersby. Regina faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. 

Regina plans to use this KES 15,000 loan to purchase bundles of women's dresses and baby clothing. Regina dreams of establishing her own shop instead of selling from door-to-door. She decided to work with Yehu to access loans and expand her business to satisfy her customers’ needs.

loans.use: to purchase women's dresses and baby clothing.

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice is a married woman with six children, two boys and four girls, one of whom still attends school. The family owns a house that has no electricity nor piped water. Beatrice's greatest monthly expenses are food, clothing and school fees. 

Beatrice operates a firewood sales business, selling in a shop to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of competition from other firewood sellers in the area. Beatrice dreams of establishing a retail shop in the future.

Beatrice plans to use this KES 25,000 loan to purchase a bundle of firewood for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve her living standards.

loans.use: to purchase firewood for resale.

loans.name: Reynold

texts.en:
Reynold B. is from the village of Villa Victoria Echague. He is 54 years old, married and has 3 adult-aged children. Reynold owns and operates a farming business, planting and harvesting rice for sale. Reynold has been engaged in his business for over 25 years and earns approximately 30,000 PHP per harvest.

In 2011, Reynold joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Reynold is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Reynold from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise

loans.name: Rolly

texts.en:
Rolly S. is from the village of Villa Victoria Echague, Isabela. He is 54 years old. Rolly is married and has five adult children. Rolly owns and operates a farm. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Rolly has been engaged in his business for over 15 years and earns approximately 20,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) every harvest season. 

In 2011, Rolly joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to do business. Rolly is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Rolly from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisher-folk and small entrepreneurs. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise

loans.name: Sophia

texts.en:
Sophia is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She lives in a rental house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are for food and rent. 

Sophia has been a food vendor for the past three years, selling food at the market to market dwellers and from home to her neighbors. Sophia decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve her living standards.

To meet her customers’ needs, she is requesting 20,000 KES to build a food vending stall. She will need to purchase iron sheeting and timber and to pay for labor.

loans.use: to build a food vending stall

loans.name: Sreyrath

texts.en:
Mrs. Sreyrath E. (shown in the photo) is 31 years old and her husband, Mr. Vanna Say, is 30 years old. They live in a village off of National Road Number Two, about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have been married since 2000 and have two young children: one son and one daughter.

Sreyrath and her husband are garment factory workers. She is applying for her first loan of $1,000 to purchase a motorbike for commuting.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for commuting.

loans.name: Pauline

texts.en:
Pauline M. is married with two children in school. Her husband is a businessman, and his salary helps provide for the family’s basic needs. Pauline has operated a poultry business for the past two years, selling chickens from home to her neighbors and local residents. She faces the challenge of dealing with outbreaks of diseases affecting poultry, which would result in losses for her.

Pauline decided to join Yehu because of its efficiency and variety of loan products. With a 20,000 KES loan she will purchase chicken feed. Pauline dreams of expanding her business and supplying poultry at wholesale prices to hotel operators in the future.

loans.use: to purchase chicken feed

loans.name: Seng

texts.en:
Seng R., 35, is a mother of four single children, two of whom are employed as fish catchers in their community, and they always contribute their profit to Seng R.. She is married to Dorm Dieng, 38, who earns a living fishing along the river. 

Seng R. sells the fish that she gets from her husband and other fishermen. She has been selling fish since 2000. She has a lot of regular clients as her store is located in the busy market. Recently, they haven’t caught as many fish because their boat engine has often broken. Therefore, Seng R. is applying for a loan to buy a new engine and to buy new tools to replace some of her old tools that are ruined.

loans.use: To buy a new machine and to buy new tools to replace some of her old tools that are ruined.

loans.name: Pha

texts.en:
Mrs. Pha J. (pictured here) is 32 years old and her husband, Mr. Lekh Lonh, is 31 years old. They have been married since 2001 and have two young children: one son and one daughter. They are living on an Island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. 

Pha is a weaver. Her husband has full-time employment. He is a lathe operator. Pha is asking for a loan of $500 to build a restroom for family use.

loans.use: To build a restroom for family use.

loans.name: Mirzorajab

texts.ru: Муминов Мирзорачаб проживает в районе Рудаки. Ему 39 лет. Он женат. Имеет 3 детей. Жена, домохозяйка. Сам Мирзорачаб имеет высшее образование, химик. По профессии проработал 18 лет. На сегодняшний день он занимается изготовлением и ремонтом ювелирных изделий. В этой сфере имеет богатый опыт. Кредит берет для приобретения оборудования, чтобы изготовить более качественное изделие.
texts.en: Mirzorajab M. lives in the Rudaki Region. He is 39 years old. He is married, with three children. His wife is a homemaker. Mirzorajab has graduated from college. He is a chemist. He has worked in his profession for 18 years. At present his line of work is making and repairing jewelry. He has a lot of experience in this area. He is taking out a loan to purchase equipment in order to ensure higher quality of his products.

loans.use: to purchase equipment for making jewelry

loans.name: Safia Amjad Masih's Group

texts.en:
Safia is 31 years old and has no child yet. She spends most of her time at home doing household tasks. Safia lives in Jaranwala, which is a small city in Pakistan’s Punjab known for its agricultural activity. She has been living there with her family in a four-room brick house for the last four years.

Safia’s husband is A. M., and he is a vegetable vendor who gets up early in the morning to go to vegetable shops. His clients are mainly people who sell vegetables from their shops in different areas of the city. He provides them with fresh vegetables and so earns a good profit.

Safia is a client of Kiva’s partner Asasah; this will be her second loan with them. During her previous loan year, she paid her installments on time and never missed a single meeting. Safia has now applied for a loan for the further improvement of her husband’s business. With the loan he will buy fresh vegetables in bulk to sell through his own shop.

Safia is hopeful that such an investment will improve his business and increase his monthly income.

loans.use: To buy fresh vegetables in bulk to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase dry fish and cooking oil.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more stock for her store

loans.name: Mergeline

texts.en:
Mergeline is a 43-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating a general store and selling vegetables.  She lives in the island of Palawan. 

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2004 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store and vegetable businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 8,000. 

Mergeline is borrowing PHP 19,000 to purchase more stock to sell.  This will be her 14th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 19,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Mergeline aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way.

loans.use: to purchase more stock to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Vedi

texts.en:
Vedi is a single man who owns a house that has neither electricity, nor piped water. He has operated his business of construction supplies and building of residential houses for the last year. 

Vedi faces a major challenge of high cost of purchasing construction materials in his business. With the 20,000 KES he is requesting, he wants to purchase materials to finish up building of residential houses. He dreams of expanding and constructing many residential houses in the future. Vedi decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: to purchase materials to finish building residential houses

loans.name: Lilia

texts.en:
Lilia is a married woman who lives in the island Palawan. She earns her living by selling fruits and vegetables. Her husband Cresencio, who is 56 years old, works as a farmer to earn his living and helps in his wife's business activities.  They have eight children who are between 10 and 31 years old. 

Lilia joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Lilia has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 14,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 9,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her eighth loan, she is borrowing PHP 17,000, which she intends to use as additional capital for selling fruits and vegetables so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children. Lilia is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.use: to buy fruits and vegetables to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to start a barber shop business and purchase a hair-cutting machine

loans.name: Buth

texts.en:
Buth S. is an older man who has been living in city of Phnom Penh. Buth S. has learned how to combine different kinds of tree roots for natural medicines and he uses his knowledge to earn an income in order to meet the needs of the family. Buth S. also travels to sell his medicine by walking around his community. 

Buth is married to 45-year-old, Sors Haminas, who stays at home to manage the  household work. They have four single children and one married one who lives away from home. Buth S. is concerned that he is always walking to sell and he dreams of having a vehicle to pick up his medicine, but he doesn’t have money yet to buy one. Thus, Buth S. would like to take a loan to purchase a secondhand motorcycle for his work-related transportation.

loans.use: To purchase a secondhand motorcycle for his transportation.

loans.name: Liberty

texts.en: Liberty is a married woman who lives in Sofronio Espanola, Palawan. She earns her living by buying and selling rice (palay), operating a general store and farming. Her husband Sebastian, who is 47 years old, works as a farmer to earn his living and helps in his wife's business activities. They have six children who are between 10 and 18 years old. Liberty joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 13 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Liberty has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 23,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 6,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 14th loan, she is borrowing PHP 25,000 to purchase rice to sell and fertilizer for her farming operation so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children and expansion of business. Liberty is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.use: to purchase rice to sell and fertilizer for her farm

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Elnora

texts.en:
Elnora is a 42-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating a general store and selling fish.  She lives in the island of Palawan. 

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2007 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store and selling fish, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 10,000. 

Elnora is borrowing PHP 12,000 to purchase stock for her store and fish to sell. This will be her fourth loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 8,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Elnora aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way.

loans.use: To purchase stock for her general store and fish

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Paz

texts.en: Paz is a 55-year-old widow who supports her family by operating a general store. She lives in Bogo, Cebu. Paz joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2010 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her first loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Paz has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 5,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 8,900, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her second loan, she is borrowing PHP 10,000 to buy stock for her general store so that she can continue to save up for future family needs. Paz is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.use: to purchase stock for her general store

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Lilibeth

texts.en:
Lilibeth P. is from the village of Del Pilar, Cabatuan, Isabela. She is 47 years old. Lilibeth is married and has 4 adult-aged children. To make a living, Lilibeth owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling daily use products such as body spray, deodorants and lotions in the local community. Lilibeth has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Lilibeth joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lilibeth is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and increase working capital. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Lilibeth from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory.

loans.name: Presina

texts.en:
Presina P. is from the village of Del Pilar, Cabatuan, Isabela. She is 45 years old. She is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Presina owns and operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Presina has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

Presina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Presina from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Luzviminda

texts.en: Luzviminda is a 54-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating a vegetable garden. She lives in the municipality of Narra, Palawan. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2003 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her vegetable garden business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 12,000. Luzviminda is borrowing PHP 24,000 to purchase fertilizers and seeds for her vegetable garden.  This will be her 14th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 22,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Luzviminda aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and seeds for her garden

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase sacks of vegetables and sacks of dry fish to sell

loans.name: Evangeline

texts.en: Evangeline is a married woman who lives in Narra, Palawan. She earns her living by raising pigs, catering food and tailoring. Her husband Felipe, who is 51 years old, works as a tricycle driver to earn his living and helps in his wife's business activities.  They have four children who are between 18 and 31 years old. Evangeline joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past eight loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Evangeline has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 18,500 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 15,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her ninth loan, she is borrowing PHP 17,000 to purchase pigs and feed so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children. Evangeline is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.use: To purchase feed and additional pigs to raise

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a cow for slaughter in his butcher shop.

loans.name: Blue Mary

texts.en:
Blue Mary is 45 years old and single with one child. Blue Mary works very hard to provide for them. Blue Mary runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 20,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more stock for her general store.

Blue Mary has been in this business for four years and sells a variety of items. Blue Mary also earns income with a farm (rice and sugarcane). In the future, Blue Mary would like to put up a little hardware someday.

loans.use: to purchase more stock for her general store

loans.name: Fernando

texts.en:
Fernando O. is from the village of Olango. He is 41 years old. Fernando is married and has four school-aged children. Fernando owns and operates a farm. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Fernando has been engaged in his business for over two years and earns approximately 35,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) per harvest. 

In 2011, Fernando joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to do business. Fernando is requesting a new loan of 27,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Fernando from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of his children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisher-folk and small entrepreneurs. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Maxima

texts.en:
Maxima M. is from the town of Naguilan, Isabela. She is 59 years old. Maxima is married and has 6 adult-aged children. To make a living, Maxima owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting a variety of vegetables for sale. Maxima has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Maxima joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maxima is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Maxima from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Solomon

texts.en:
Solomon K. is 55 years old and married to Sally Chepkosgei who is a house wife. They have 5 children, aged 21, 19, 14, 12 and 8 years old. Solomon owns a grocery in Ndurio trading centre and has been in business for a period of 6 years. His monthly income is KES 8,100.

Solomon has joined KADET LTD and taken a loan of KES 10,000, this being his first loan. He hopes to use the money to purchase onions, tomatoes and green vegetables for his business. The profits will be used to start a retail shop.

His dream is to educate his children to higher levels and also to prosper in the business.

loans.use: To add more retail inventory.

loans.name: Perveen's Group

texts.en:
Perveen has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to financially assist her husband who runs a grocery store in the community. Through his store, he sells daily use items such as salt, sugar, cooking oil and lentils.  With the loan, he will buy groceries in bulk to put into his store to fulfill customer demands and to make larger profits. Perveen is hopeful that her husband, who has been operating this business for the past 2 years, will be successful and be able to get the desired results from his business after making the loan investment. 

Perveen is a very supportive lady and always supports her family. As a housewife, she stays at home and takes care of her household responsibilities. She has 3 sons and 3 daughters. Her eldest son works in the fields and grows different seasonal crops. A second son is a diver by profession, while the youngest one operates a Punjabi food restaurant business. Her daughters are studying in a local school. 

She has been living in Jaranwala for many years with her family in a 2-room brick house. Jaranwala is a small city of Punjab, Pakistan and known for its agriculture industry. 

Perveen is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her second loan application. In the previous loan year, she has proved herself as a responsible client who always paid her installments on time.

loans.use: to buy groceries for a grocery store business

loans.name: Smas

texts.en:
Smas R., 46, is a humble mother who has three children. All of her children are learning at the local public school. Currently, Smas R. stays at home to do housework and assists in her husband’s business. 

The financial income for this family comes from her husband's business. He sells different kinds of merchandise from province to province. He also buys items in bulk, on credit, from market sellers in Phnom Penh. He then supplies his products to people who are sellers in small markets in each province. Smas R. says that her husband’s enterprise is a very profitable one and he is able to earn enough money to meet her family's needs. She would like to ask for a loan for her husband to buy additional merchandise for resale.

loans.use: To buy additional merchandise for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a fridge to store perishable goods in his retail shop

loans.name: Carolina

texts.en:
Carolina M. is from the town of Naguillan, Isabela. She is 45 years old. Carolina is married and has six school-aged children. Carolina owns and operates a piggery. The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Carolina has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. 

In 2011, Carolina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to do business. Carolina is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Carolina from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisher-folk and small entrepreneurs. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn is 55 years old and is a married woman. She lives with her family in the town of Sto. Niño, South Cotabato.

Evelyn and her husband are both farmers. They primarily plant and harvest rice crops. Evelyn rents a stall in the market to sell their harvest. Evelyn also grows pigs in their backyard. The pigs are for fattening and sale.

Evelyn requested a loan of 15000 Philippine pesos (PHP), which she will use to to purchase pig feed, seeds and other farm inputs. Evelyn wishes for their harvest to increase.

loans.use: to purchase pig feed, seeds, and other farm inputs

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn works hard to support six children. Jocelyn is a married woman and earns a living buying and selling rice in the Philippines.

Jocelyn requested a PHP 13,000 loan through NWTF to buy more rice to sell. Jocelyn has been in this business for five years. 

In the future, Jocelyn would like to expand her business and support the needs of the family.

loans.use: to buy more rice to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Ruben

texts.en:
Ruben D. is from the village of Binuangan, Misamis Oriental. He is 46 years old. Ruben is married. Ruben owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, junk foods & beverages in the local community. Ruben has been engaged in his business for over six years and earns approximately 15,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. 

In 2002, Ruben joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to do business. Ruben has successfully repaid a previous loan of 25,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Ruben is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods & junk foods. This loan will be the 15th loan taken out by Ruben from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods & junk foods

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, sugar, salt and rice to sell.

loans.name: Ruqqiya's Group

texts.en:
Ruqqiya lives in Jaranwala, a small city of Punjab Pakistan that is known for its agriculture industry. She has been living there with her family in a 2-room brick house for the past 8 years. 

She is the mother of 4 sons and a daughter. Her sons do different kind of work to contribute to the family's finances. Her daughter, who is 14 years old, is only able to attend school and is studying in the 8th class. 

Ruqqiya has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to expand her milk-selling business by purchasing another buffalo. She started operating this business after the death of her husband a few years ago. Now the business is well established as Ruqqiya has a good number of clients in her community who buy milk from her due to the milk's freshness and good quality. She is hopeful that by purchasing another buffalo, her business will grow due to increased productivity of milk and her ability to serve more clients. 

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her second loan application. In the previous loan year, she paid her installments on time and never missed a single meeting.

Note:  In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Ruqqiya.

loans.use: to buy another buffalo for milk-selling business

loans.name: Carina

texts.en:
Carina C. is from the village of Tipolohon, Claveria, Misamis Oriental. She is 31 years old and married, with 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Carina runs a sari-sari (variety) store, where she sells products for daily use such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, snack food, detergent and beverages. Carina has been engaged in her business for more than 9 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Carina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Carina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Carina is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell such as canned goods and snack foods. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Carina from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell such as canned goods and snack food

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en: As a married woman and parent of three children, Jocelyn is a very hard working entrepreneur. Jocelyn is 44 years old and has one child who is in school. Jocelyn has a food vending business in the Philippines. Jocelyn requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to purchase ingredients that she cooks for for her food vending business. For 20 years, Jocelyn has been in this business. In the future, Jocelyn would like to engage in buying and selling of livestock and expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase ingredients to cook for her food vending business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Janet

texts.en: Janet is a 37-year-old widow who supports her family by operating a rice mill and a sari-sari store. She lives in Hinigaran, Negros Occidental. Janet joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past six loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Janet has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 20,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 15,000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her seventh loan, she is borrowing PHP 20,000 to pay for more maintenance on her rice mill so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children and family needs. Janet is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.use: To maintain her rice mill

loans.name: Ma. Cristina

texts.en:
Ma. Cristina is 30 years old and single.

Ma. Cristina runs a general store in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 20,000 loan through NWTF to purchase different stock.

Ma. Cristina has been in this business for two years and sells a variety of items. Ma. Cristina also earns income as a dealer of AVON products. 

In the future, Ma. Cristina would like to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase different stock for her general store

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Ligaya

texts.en: Ligaya A.'s main source of income comes from buying and selling green bananas in her community. She is 49 years old, married and has four grown-up children. She is from the village of Tipolohon, Claveria, Misamis Oriental. Ligaya has been in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2009, Ligaya joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from HSPFI which was used to purchase additional bananas and for working capital. Ligaya is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional bananas to sell. This will be her second loan from HSPFI. She plans to use additional income to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional bananas to sell.

loans.name: Beverlie

texts.en: Beverlie is a married woman who lives in the island of Cebu. She earns her living by operating a general store. Her husband Angelo, who is 57 years old, works as a fisherman to earn his living and helps in his wife's business activities.  Beverlie joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past six loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Beverlie has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 5,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 6,700, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her seventh loan, she is borrowing PHP 10,000 to buy groceries items to resell so that she can continue to save up for future house repair. Beverlie is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.use: to purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Fely

texts.en:
Sixty-year-old Fely is a married woman living in the town of Sto. Niño, South Cotabato. She raised her children in the same town.

Fely is a farmer. She cultivates her land for planting and harvesting rice crops. Fely sells her harvest to her town's market. She says it is easier to sell rice than other crops because it is a main Filipino food.

Fely requested a loan of 15,000 PHP, which she will use to purchase seeds, fertilizers, and other farm inputs. In the future, Fely wishes to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizers, and other farm inputs

loans.name: Nelly

texts.en:
Nelly is a 50-year-old married woman with four children. With one of her children in school, Nelly works very hard to provide for them.

Nelly runs a general store in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional stock for her general store.
