Nelly has been in this business for 15 years and sells a variety of items. Nelly also earns income as a retailer of gasoline and charcoal. 

In the future, Nelly would like to finish the education of her child and to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional stock for her general store

loans.name: Pilar

texts.en:
As a married woman and parent of nine children, Pilar is a very hard working entrepreneur. Pilar is 55 years old. Three of her children are in school.

Pilar has a general store business in the Philippines. Pilar requested a PHP 25,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more stock to sell. Aside from that, she also has a ready to wear clothes business and is a motorcycle operator.

For 13 years, Pilar has been in this business. In the future, Pilar would like to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Nelia

texts.en: Nelia is a married woman who lives in Toledo, Cebu. She earns her living by operating a general store. Her husband Pablo, who is 59 years old, works as a vendor to earn his living and helps in his wife's business activities.  They have three children who are between 31 and 36 years old. Nelia joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2001 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 18 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Nelia has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 29,500 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 9,800, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 19th loan, she is borrowing PHP 29,500 to buy soft drinks, curls, candy, bread and other goods so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her grandchildren. Nelia is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.use: To purchase more goods to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Rica

texts.en:
Rica is 35 years old and married with four children. With three of her children in school, Rica works very hard to provide for them.

Rica runs a general store in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional stock to sell.

Rica has been in this business for two years and sells a variety of items.

In the future, Rica would like to expand her general store.

loans.use: to purchase additional stock to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is married with four school-going children. Her husband is a primary school teacher and he contributes to the provision of the family's basic needs. They own a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. 

Josephine has operated a water-selling business for the past two years, selling from her home to her neighbors and to passersby. She faces the challenge of water shortages during the dry, hot season. Josephine dreams of establishing a food vending business in the future.

With the 20,000 Kenyan shilling loan she is requesting, she wants to purchase four handcarts for water distribution and 50 water cans. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase four handcarts for water distribution and 50 water cans.

loans.name: Gemma

texts.en:
Gemma (nicknamed Fely) M. is a 47-year old married woman with one child. Fely is engaged in farming. 

She and her husband, who is also a farmer, till their land together. They plant and harvest rice crops. Part of the harvest is used for family consumption and the rest is sold to their community.

Fely needs fertilizers and other farm inputs. She is requesting a loan of 15,000 Philippines pesos (PHP), which she will use to supply her farm. Fely hopes to create a stable business.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs.

loans.name: Mary Ann

texts.en:
Mary Ann works hard to support her two children. Mary Ann is a married woman and has a general store business in the Philippines. Mary Ann has been in this business for three years.  

Mary Ann requested a PHP 20,000 loan through NWTF to buy merchandise to sell in her general store.

In the future, Mary Ann would like to put up a livestock business.

loans.use: to buy more merchandise to sell in her general store

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Jessica

texts.en:
Jessica is a 35-year old married woman. Her husband is a farmer and a driver. They have four children, the oldest of whom is 14 years old. 

Jessica is also a farmer. She and her husband till their farm to plant and harvest rice crops. Jessica also grows pigs in her backyard. Their harvest and grown pigs are sold to their town's market.

Jessica's loan will be used to purchase pig feeds, fertilizers, and other farm inputs. Jessica works hard to build her business. She wishes to have a stable income and for her children to finish college.

loans.use: to purchase pig feeds, fertilizers, and other farm inputs.

loans.name: Julieta

texts.en: Julieta is a married woman from the province of Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating three business ventures: a sari-sari store, an Avon dealership (beauty products direct seller) and fish vending. Her husband Peter is 60 years old. They have five children who are 17 to 34 years old. Julieta joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 11 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Julieta has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 15,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 2,400, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 12th loan, she is borrowing PHP 19,500 to buy merchandise to sell in her sari-sari store and in her other businesses so that she can continue to save up for the future for her kids' schooling and home improvement. Julieta is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.use: to purchase merchandise to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Janette

texts.en:
Janette is a 44-year old married woman. She has three children, the oldest of whom is 27 years old. Her husband is a farmer.

Janette is also a farmer. She and her husband own and till a farm land in the town of Sto. Niño, South Cotabato. They primarily plant rice crops, which they sell to the market once harvested.

Janette is requesting a loan that she will use to purchase farm fertilizers and other inputs. Janette works hard to sustain her family.

loans.use: to purchase farm fertilizers and other inputs.

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is a married woman with six children, all of whom attend school. She has operated a tailoring business for the past three years, selling from her home to her neighbours and passersby. She also earns her other source of living from charcoal sales.

With the 30,000 Kenyan shilling loan, she wants to purchase cloth and thread, and to have her sewing machine serviced. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase cloth, thread and service her sewing machine.

loans.name: Merlita

texts.en: Merlita is a 48-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating two business ventures: a general store and food vending. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2007 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store and food vending businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 5,000. Merlita is borrowing PHP 11,000 to buy more merchandise to sell in her general store and ingredients for her food vending business. This will be her fifth loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 9,500, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Merlita aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way.

loans.use: to buy more products to sell

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en: Evelyn is a 40-year-old widow who supports her family by fishing and fish vending. She lives in Escalante City, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2003 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her fishing and fish vending businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 5,600. Evelyn is borrowing PHP 15,000 to purchase fishing net and more fish to sell. This will be her 15th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 10,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Evelyn aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way.

loans.use: to purchase fishing net and more fish to sell

loans.name: Kaphuli

texts.en:
Kaphuli is married with six school going-children. She has operated her retail shop for the past three years, selling to her local neighbours. Kaphuli sells daily consumable products like maize flour, wheat flour, biscuits and tea leaves at her retail shop. 

With the 30,000 Kenyan shilling loan she is requesting she wants to purchase a bundle of wheat flour, tea leaves and biscuits for sale. She decided to join Yehu to have access to loans and business expertise. She dreams of establishing a supermarket in the future.

loans.use: To purchase bundle of wheat flour, tea leaves and biscuits for sale.

loans.name: Jopeth Jay

texts.en:
Jopeth is a young farmer (21 years old), living in the town of Sto. Niño, South Cotabato. He is still single and is helping his family financially.

Jopeth is a farmer and pig-grower. He plants and harvests rice crops that he sells to the market. The pigs he grows are for fattening and sale. 

Jopeth desires his business to grow. He requested for a loan of 15,000 Philippines pesos (PHP), which he will use to purchase piglets, feed, and farm fertilizers. Jopeth is also saving for his future.

loans.use: to purchase piglets, feed, and farm fertilizers.

loans.name: Thelma

texts.en:
Thelma is a widow who lives in Negros Occidental, Philippines. She earns her living by operating a general store. She has two children who are 25 and 37 years old. 

Thelma joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past six loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Thelma has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 14,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 3,200, uplifting the family's standard of living. 

This time, for her seventh loan, she is borrowing PHP 15,000 to pay for more stock for her general store so that she can continue to save up for the future to expand her business. Thelma is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.use: to purchase more stock to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty works hard to support her five children. Betty is married and has a motorcycle transport business in the Philippines.

Betty requested a PHP 18,000 loan through NWTF to buy her mechanic's tools.

Betty has been in this business for five (5) years.  

In the future, Betty would like to increase her income and develop her transport operation.

loans.use: To purchase new mechanic's tools

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is 50 years old and is a married woman. She and her family live in Sto. Niño, South Cotabato. Her husband works as a farmer.

Josephine is also a farmer. She says that she and her husband prepare their land well to plant rice crops. Josephine sells their harvest to rice traders. She and her husband work hard to improve their living conditions.

Josephine's loan will be used to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs. In the future, Josephine hopes to have a stable business.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Basilia

texts.en: Basilia is a widow who lives in Negros Oriental, Philippines. She earns her living by operating three business ventures: a sari-sari store, pig fattening and a pedicab business. She has eight children who are 33 to 49 years old. Basilia joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2003 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 10 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Basilia has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 35,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 40,000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 11th loan, she is borrowing PHP 40,000 to purchase merchandise to sell in her sari-sari store so that she can continue to save up for future family needs and for business. Basilia is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.use: to purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Lyroche

texts.en:
Lyroche is a 45-year old married woman. She has a 25-year old child. Her husband works as a jeepney dispatcher in their town. (Jeepneys are a popular means of public transportation in the Philippines.) 

Lyroche has been in the business of raising hogs for quite some time now. She plans to use her loan to purchase additional piglets and feed. Lyroche works hard to improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase additional piglets and feed.

loans.name: Rocelyn

texts.en: Rocelyn is a married woman who lives in Narra, Palawan. She earns her living by farming rice and selling it at a wholesale and retail basis. Her husband Sonny, who is 38 years old, works as a farmer to earn his living and helps in his wife's business activities.  They have three children who are between 11 and 18 years old. Rocelyn joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2006 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past nine loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Rocelyn has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 19,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 5,500, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 10th loan, she is borrowing PHP 20,000 to buy fertilizers for her rice farm so that she can continue to save up for future improvement of business. Rocelyn is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer for her rice farm

loans.name: Rosemelia

texts.en: Rosemelia is a 43-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating three business ventures: trucking for hire, pig fattening and chainsaw businesses. She lives in Tanjay City, Negros Oriental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2000 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 40,000. Rosemelia is borrowing PHP 29,500 so that she can purchase spare parts to maintain her truck in good running condition.  This will be her 17th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 29,500, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Rosemelia aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way.

loans.use: to buy spare parts for her truck

loans.name: Milagrosa

texts.en:
Milagrosa is a 42-year-old woman living in the town of Sto. Niño, South Cotabato, with her family. She is engaged in a farming and hog-raising business. She plants and harvests rice crops that she sells to her town's market. The pigs she raises are for fattening and sale also. Milagrosa does her best to sustain her family.

Milagrosa's loan will be used to purchase seed, fertilizers and pig feed. She wishes to have a stable business.

loans.use: to purchase seed, fertilizers and pig feed.

loans.name: Pelba

texts.en: Pelba is a 57-year-old married woman with four children. The oldest child is 32 years old and the youngest is 24. Pelba and her husband are both farmers. They till their land well in order to plant rice crops. Their harvest is used for family consumption and sold to traders. Pelba's loan will be used to purchase seeds and fertilizers. She hopes to have an increased harvest.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and fertilizers.

loans.name: Vatan

texts.en:
Vatan A. is 40 years old and a married man. He has three dependent sons who are between 11 and 15 years old. Vatan and his family live in a small settlement built for refugee families, in Bilasuvar district. He fled to Bilasuvar in the beginning of the 1990s. 

Vatan earns his living by operating a business buying and selling sheep. His wife helps him in his business activities. Being in this business for many years, Vatan knows very well how to choose the animals, how to breed them and look after them. 

He is planning to expand his herd and purchase more sheep. For this reason he requested a loan from Aqroinvest and Kiva. This is his first loan in the amount of 1000 AZN. He bought seven sheep. The income from this loan helps pay for his children's education and feed his family.

loans.use: to buy seven sheep.

loans.name: Upatanisho Group

texts.fr: Kavira P.  est entrepreneur, leader du groupe d’affaire Upatanisho, âgée de 48 ans, mariée, mère de 9 enfants dont certains ont leurs propres foyers et  d’autres vont encore à l’école. Son mari est chômeur, sans emploi. La  cliente  Kavira P. est vendeuse d’huile de palme et l’huile végétal raffiné Rina. Elle expose ses marchandises au long de la rue et parfois à son domicile. Bientôt 7 ans qu’elle exerce cette activité. Elle démarra son activité avec un fonds de crédit reçu de l’IMF Hekima vers 2004. Ce nouveau crédit doit lui servir de s’approvisionner  avec  des nouvelles marchandises (6 bidons d’huile de palme et 4 cartons d’huile végétal raffiné Rina, 2 sacs de farines, etc.).  En plus, elle ambitionne agrandir son entreprise et construire dignement une belle maison pour  sa famille. Selon elle, le crédit de Hekima lui a servi  de vivre dans des conditions de vie  socialement  acceptables. La cliente Kavira P.  remercie l’IMF Hekima et ses partenaires pour  leurs actions dédiées aux pauvres femmes exclues de banque classique. Le groupe Upatanisho est constitué de 28 membres.
texts.en: Kavira P. is an entrepreneur and the leader of the Upatanisho work group. She is 48 years old, married, and the mother of nine. Some of her children already live separately, and others still go to school. Her husband is unemployed, out of work. Kavira P. sells palm oil and refined vegetable oil of the Rina brand. She displays her wares out on the street and sometimes by her home. She has been doing this for almost seven years. She launched her business with a  starting capital received from IMF Hekima around 2004. This new loan will allow her to stock up additional goods (six jugs of palm oils, four cartons of Rina refined vegetables oil, two bags of flour, etc). In addition her goal is to expand her business and to build a nice, proper house for her family to live in. She says that Hekima’s loan has helped her maintain a socially acceptable standard of living. As  a client, Kavira P. is grateful to IMF Hekima and its partners for their assistance to impoverished women who do not have access to traditional banking. The Upatanisho group consists of 28 members.

loans.use: to purchase six jugs of palm oil, four cartons of vegetable oil, two bags of flour, etc

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Mougnou [Patience] Group

texts.fr:
Mougnou est un regroupement de femmes du quartier Médina Koura de Koutiala qui vivent dans de grandes familles traditionnelles avec leurs maris, enfants et autres parents. Elles ont en moyenne 32 ans, sont mariées et mères d’au moins 4 enfants.
Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce d’articles divers tels, l’atieké de manioc les condiments alimentaires, le savons, etc. 
 Pour augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso il y a 1 an. Elles sont à leur deuxième prêt de groupe et le prêt précédent  a été bien remboursé.  
Kadia M. est un membre du groupe Mougnou qui vend de l’atieké  (couscous à base de manioc très  apprécié par les Maliens).  
Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, des chargements de charrettes en  de bois de chauffe auprès des producteurs pour la cuisson de l’atieké et des sacs de maniocs au fur et à mesure. Elle vend  de l’atieké en détail et au comptant au  marché  de Médina Koura, à une clientèle diverse et variée. 
Tandis que les membres du groupe Mougnou comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 80 000FCFA  chacune au  cours de ce cycle, Kadia  compte réaliser 90.000FCFA.  
En plus du remboursement des prêts, elles utilisent une partie du revenu  pour faire face aux dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
Mougnou ["patience"] is a group of women from the Médina Koura district of Koutiala living in traditional extended families with their husbands, children, and other relatives. They are all married, and average 32 years of age and at least four children. This group of women sells various items, such as “atieke” [a traditional dish], food condiments, soap etc. In order to expand the scope of their business, one year ago the group members decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso credit program. They are now on their second group loan, having duly reimbursed the previous loan.

Kada M. is a group member who sells “atieké” (a couscous-like dish made with manioc [cassava] and very popular in Mali).
She plans to use her loan to purchase cartloads of heating wood from the farmers, to be used for cooking  atieké, as well as bags of manioc as necessary. She retails her atieké for cahs at the Médina Koura market, to a very diverse  customer base. While other members of the Mougnou group plan to achieve an average monthly income of 80,000 West African francs each in the course of this loan cycle, Kadia plans to earn 90,000 francs. Apart from repaying the loan, they use part of their revenues to cover everyday family expenses.

loans.use: to purchase manioc and heating wood

loans.name: Soutoura Group

texts.fr:
SOUTOURA  est un regroupement de 7 femmes ayant en moyenne trente cinq ans, six enfants et vivant  dans des familles traditionnelle à MANA, un des quartiers de la ville de OUELESSEBOUGOU (2ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles sont à leur première collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. 
Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce du charbon de bois, à l’image de  Assan  T., du bois de chauffe, etc.
Assan  T.  compte acheter avec son  prêt,  40 sacs de charbons de bois. Elle s’approvisionne à MANA  et marchés  environnants  auprès des grossistes. Elle effectue sa vente au  marché de Ouelessebougou ,BAMAKO et à domicile à une clientèle composée essentiellement de femmes, en détail, au comptant et à crédit. 
Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 10.000FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée  pour l’appui de son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
SOUTOURA is a group comprising seven women, who average 35 years of age and six children. They live in traditional families in MANA, a neighborhood in the city of OUELESSEBOUGOU (2nd administrative region of Mali).

They are seeking their first loan from Kiva's partner, the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso, in order to meet customer demand. The members of this group buy and sell charcoal and firewood, as does Assan T..

Assan  T. intends to use her share of the loan to buy 40 sacks of charcoal. She gets her supplies from wholesalers in MANA and in the surrounding markets. She retails at the market in OUELESSEBOUGOU, in BAMAKO, and at her home, to a clientele comprising mostly women, for cash and on credit.

She foresees turning an average monthly profit of XOF 10'000 (ca US$ 20), to be used in part to help her husband with the daily expenses. The remainder will be reinvested in her business.

loans.use: to buy 40 sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Daouda

texts.fr:
Monsieur DAOUDA T. est un homme marié qui est âgé de 45 ans et  père de 7 enfants. Il vit dans une famille polygame avec ses deux épouses, ses enfants et ses parents à KELEYA,  une commune rurale située à 60 km de la préfecture de Bougouni (troisième région administrative du Mali).
DAOUDA est un boucher qui mène son activité depuis 10 ans et compte utiliser ce prêt pour l’achat de trois bœufs à abattre pour satisfaire sa demande journalière qui s’accroît. Il vend à  la place du marché de son village avec une clientèle constituée des ménages et restaurants.
Il compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 150.000 FCFA, Monsieur  DAOUDA T.  est à son deuxième prêt et désire  à la longue établir une boucherie moderne avec le programme de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso.
texts.en:
Mr. Daouda T. is a 45-year-old married man and a father of seven children. He lives in a polygamous family with his two wives, his children, and his parents in KELEYA, a rural commune located 60 km from the prefecture of Bougouni (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

Daouda is a butcher who has been managing his business for ten years. He plans on using this loan for buying three heads of cattle to slaughter in order to meet the daily demand, which is growing. He makes his sales at the market square in his village. His customer base is composed of households and restaurants. He plans on making an average monthly profit of 150,00 francs CFA.

Daouda is on his second loan. In the long run, he would like to establish a modern butcher shop with the help of the program at the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso.

loans.use: to buy cattle for slaughter

loans.name: Issa

texts.fr:
Monsieur  ISSA S. est un homme  qui est âgé de 48 ans qui vit avec ses six enfants et son épouse dans une famille traditionnelle dans le village de Dongorona, sous  préfecture de OUELESSEBOUGOU,  Région de Koulikoro.
Afin de s’insérer dans la vie économique, ISSA S., qui n’a pas eu la chance de réussir à l’école, s’est vite initié aux activités de stockage commercialement des céréales et des produits de cueillettes tels le néré, les noix d’acajou et  le tamarin.  
Nanti  de deux années d’expériences dans le domaine, il est très sollicité.
Dans ses recherches de ressources financières complémentaires, ISSA S. décide d’adhérer au programme crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui il est à son premier prêt individuel.
ISSA  compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 1 tonne de maïs, 1 tonne  d’arachide et 5 sacs de grain de néré, auprès des paysans producteurs de DAFARA et de Ouelessebougou qu’il stockera pendant au moins 2 mois. Il effectue sa vente  au marché de Ouelesseboubou, au comptant et rarement à crédit à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.  
ISSA S.  espère réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 50.000 FCFA qui   sera utilisé pour rembourser le prêt,  subvenir aux dépenses de la famille et réinvestir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
Mr. ISSA S., age 48, lives with his children and his spouse in a traditional family, in the village of Dongorona (OUELESSEBOUGOU sub-prefecture, Koulikoro Region). In order to enter economic life, ISSA S., who didn't get the chance to attend school, became introduced to commercially stocking cereals and gathered fruits such as néré, cashew nuts and tamarin.

Having two years of experience in this field, he is in very high demand. While looking for complementary sources of financing, he decided to join the loan program from Kiva's partner, the microfinance organization Soro Yiriwaso, from which he is seeking his first individual loan.

ISSA intends to use the loan to buy 1 ton of corn, 1 ton of peanuts and 5 sacks of néré grains, from farmer producers in DAFARA and Ouelessebougou. He will stock it for at least two months. He resells at the market in Ouelessebougou, for cash and, rarely, on credit, to a clientele comprising both women and men.

ISSA S. hops to turn an average monthly profits of XOF 50'000 (ca US$ 105), to be used to repay the loan and provide for his family. The remainder will be reinvested in his business.

loans.use: to buy 1 ton of corn, 1 ton of peanuts, and 5 sacks of néré grains

loans.name: Seydou

texts.fr:
Monsieur  SEYDOU M.  est âgé de 46 ans qui vit avec ses six enfants et son épouse dans une famille traditionnelle à Dongorona, un des villages de la sous préfecture  de OUELESSEBOUGOU,  Région de Koulikoro.
SEYDOU M. n’a pas eu la chance  d’aller à l’école. Très tôt  il s’intéressa aux activités génératrices de revenus notamment à l’achat stockage vente de céréales. Il a appris cette activité auprès de son oncle maternel, qui  fut jadis un grand commerçant de céréales. 
Dans le souci de satisfaire sa clientèle en nette croissance, il décida de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso. Il est à son premier prêt individuel  qui servira à acheter, 2 tonnes de céréales (maïs, haricot, mil, fonio) auprès des paysans producteurs de Dongorona  et environnants qu’il gardera pendant au moins deux mois. Il vend  essentiellement en gros à une clientèle constituée de revendeurs venant des grandes villes telles Bamako.
SEYDOU M. espère réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 35.000  FCFA qui sera utilisé pour rembourser le prêt et  être réinvestir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en: Mr. Seydou M. is 46 years old and lives with his six children and his wife in a traditional family in Dongorona, a village in the sub-prefecture of Ouelessebougou, Region of Koulikoro. He did not have the chance to go to school. Early on, he became interested in revenue-generating businesses, especially the buying, storing, and selling of grains. He learned this business from his maternal uncle, who was once a major grains merchant. Concerned about satisfying his clearly growing customer base, he decided to collaborate with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso. He is now on his first individual loan that will be used to buy 2 tonnes of grains (corn, beans, millet, fonio) from peasant producers in and around Dongorona. He will keep the grains for at least two months.  He essentially sells wholesale to a customer base composed of retailers from big cities, such as Bamako. Seydou hopes to make an average monthly profit of 35,000 francs CFA that will be used to repay the loan and to reinvest in his business.

loans.use: to buy grains

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase bundles of maize flour, sacks of beans, and sugar.

loans.name: Burema Women's Group-Kihihi

texts.en:
32-year-old B. Ellias is affiliated with Burema Women's group-Kihihi. He has been doing tailoring for the past two years in Kihihi Town. Ellias who is happily married with two kids says he got apprentice training on how to sew clothes from a tailoring school in Mbarara which is a neighboring town. He says the skills he learnt had to be put into practice and at length he established his own tailoring business. 

Before all this, Ellias was tending to his farming gardens from which he harvested crops that he used to resell later. He still maintains his farming source of livelihood, saying he is able to supplement with profits from his tailoring business the little he gets from selling his crops. Weekly this business generates shillings 80,000. He says with this loan, he is going to purchase textiles for making clothing. He says he will be able to make more clothes to resell once he buys the textiles.

loans.use: to purchase more cloth to make clothing.

loans.name: Sop Mame Diarra Group

texts.fr:
Les 13 membres du groupe sont liés par une solidarité mutuelle qui est fondée par une cohabitation et des liens de parenté. Le groupe est créé depuis 10 cycles, c'est-à-dire le 06 juillet 2006. Leur principale activité est l'embouche en suite vient la vente de céréales. Le groupe fait partie du Banc Villageois de KEUR MBAR.
nb. Maguette D. et Awa L. ne figurant pas distinctement pas sur la photo sont considérées comme absentes 

Madame Khardiata S. (debout à gauche de la photo) est responsable du groupe. Elle est âgée de 27 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de 05 enfants. Elle a aussi la charge de 03 autres enfants qui lui sont confiés par des amis et proches. 

Elle fait de l'embouche ovine comme activité principale. Elle pratique cette activité depuis plus de cinq ans. 

Son nouveau crédit lui permettra d'acheter deux moutons qu'elle va emboucher pendant au moins quatre mois avant de les revendre dans les marchés hebdomadaires.

Son objectif est de participer à la prise en charge des dépenses quotidiennes de la famille, par exemple la nourriture, la santé et la scolarité des enfants.
texts.en:
The 13 members of the SOP MAME DIARRA group are bonded by mutual solidarity founded on cohabitation and kinship. The group was established 10 cycles ago, on July 6, 2006. The members' main business consists in raising sheep, followed by selling cereals. The group belongs to the KEUR MBAR Banc Villageois. Two members, Maguette D. et Awa L., are missing from the photograph.

Mrs. Khardiata S., standing on the left in the photograph, is the leader of the group. She's 27 years old, married, and the mother of five children. She also has to support three other kids, entrusted to her by friends and relatives.

Her main occupation consists in raising cattle, a business she has been running for over five years. Her new loan will enable her to buy two sheep that she will fatten for at least four months, before reselling them at weekly markets.

Her goal is to help support the daily expenses of her family, such as food, healthcare, and her children's school expenses.

loans.use: to buy two sheep to raise

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more shoes for spring

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en:
Stephen is a married man with four children; two attend school while two are still too young for school. His wife is a shopkeeper and she contributes to the upbringing of their children. They live in a rental house that has neither electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

Stephen has operated a "boda boda" ( motorcycle) business for the past two years, villagers and travelers are his potential customers. In addition he also operates a retail shop business which contributes to his monthly income to meet his family demands. 

With the loan he is requesting, he wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour and maize flour, service his motorcycle, and put in electric sockets to start a mobile charging business. Stephen dreams of expanding his business even more in the future.

loans.use: To service his motorcycle, purchase bundles of wheat flour and maize flour, and put in electric sockets to start a mobile charging business.

loans.name: Kundumurimo Group

texts.fr: Edouard Rugerinyange est commerçant de menuiserie, et client d’ACB depuis 2010.  Il à 42 ans, il est marie, et né a Rwanda.  Il a 6 enfants entre 1 an et 14 ans, et 6 personnes en charge ; quatre de ses enfants vont à l’école.  Edouard lui-même a fini 6 ans d’école primaire.  Ce crédit est son deuxième cycle avec ACB, et il a une bonne histoire de remboursement.  Il va utiliser son prêt pour acheter les articles pour son commerce de menuiserie, et sa stratégie pour la croissance de l’affaire est d’avoir un business bien et ponctuelle.  Il voudrait avoir un atelier de menuiserie, et scolariser tous ses enfants.
texts.en: Edouard Rugerinyange operates a woodworking shop and has been a client of ACB since 2010.  He is 42 years old, married and was born in Rwanda.  He has six children between the ages of 1 and 14 years, and has six people in his care.  Four of his children go to school.  Edouard himself completed six years of elementary school.  This loan is his second with ABC and he has a good repayment record.  He is going to use his loan to buy articles for his woodworking shop, and his strategy for expanding his business is to do a good job on time.  He would like to have a woodworking workshop and to educate his children.

loans.use: To buy boards for the woodworking workshop

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase gallons of petrol for sale.

loans.name: Salyibubu

texts.en:
Salyibubu T. is 45, married and has four children. She works as a nurse at the hospital and her husband is a crane driver. Salaries of the medical personnel are not high in the rural areas. For this reason, people need to find an additional means of subsistence. 

In 2002, Salyibubu decided to engage in selling meat products at the local market. She started this activity with the initial capital of 20,000 KGS and managed to earn about 16,000 KGS in a month. With the revenues, she was able to pay for the education of her elder daughters. Salyibubu has applied for a loan of 85,000 KGS to purchase 14 sheep. This will allow her to broaden her business and to help in purchasing a flat in Bishkek, the capital city. 


About Bai-Tushum: 

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase cattle.

loans.name: Harriet

texts.en:
Harriet N. lives in the Naguru neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is single and has five children, all of whom are in school.

Harriet has a business selling second hand clothes at market. She has been in this business for five years and works seven days a week.

Harriet has requested  for a loan of 600,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bales of second hand clothes. The main business challenges for Harriet include seasonality and the ever-increasing prices of second hand clothes. Her goal for her business is to become a wholesaler.

Harriet lives in a home that she owns. She has access to electricity and to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees, medication, paying utility bills and feeding the family.

loans.use: to buy  more bales of clothing

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase bundles of tomatoes and potatoes for sale

loans.name: Teddy

texts.en:
Teddy N. lives in the Ndeeba neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is single and has three children, all of whom are in school.

Teddy has a business selling bananas which she sells at market at retail. She has been in this business for ten years and she works seven days a  week.

Teddy has requested a loan of 600,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bunches of bananas. The main business challenges for Teddy include seasonality and the ever-increasing price of bananas. Her goal for her business is to become a wholesaler.

Teddy lives in a home that she owns. She has access to electricity but not to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees, medication, paying utility bills and feeding the family.

loans.use: to buy more bunches of bananas

loans.name: Rutwe Women's Group-Kihihi

texts.en:
K. Aisha, aged 40, runs a used clothing sales business in Kihihi Town. The divorced mother of one has been operating this business for the past five years. She says she started this business with capital from an agro-produce sales business. When I ask her about what she thinks has made her achieve this longevity in a business as fickle as this, she says it all boils down to diligence, prayers, good human relationship skills and a sense of determination. 

Aisha says this business generates 100,000 shillings weekly as accrued profits. She is already casting her mind to the future with a view of expanding her business into a bigger and more profitable enterprise. She says she is requesting this loan to purchase more bales of clothes to resell. She is affiliated to Rutwe Women's Group-Kihihi.

loans.use: To purchase more bales of clothes to resell

loans.name: Nakali

texts.en:
Nakali is a widow with 10 children, all of whom attend school. They own a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

Nakali has operated a restaurant business for the past four years. Her potential customers visiting the restaurant are travelers, those who are in transit. Nakali dreams of expanding her business to a hotel in the future.

With the Kshs 40,000 she wants to purchase wheat flour, maize flour and sugar. She decided to join Yehu to access funds to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase wheat flour, maize flour and sugar

loans.name: Milcah

texts.en:
Milcah is a single woman who owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are electricity and water bills. 

For the past four years, she has operated a beauty salon; her potential customers are the neighbours. Milcah faces the major challenge of seasonality. During the festive season she has many customers while during the months of January to May the number of customers is low. She dreams of establishing a hairdressing school in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase beauty products such as hair relaxer oil, shampoo and hair weaves. She decided to join Yehu because of responsiveness to customer needs.

loans.use: To purchase beauty products e.g. hair relaxer oil, shampoo and hair weaves

loans.name: Bakari

texts.en:
Bakari is married and has children. His wife operates a retail shop business which helps in the provision of the family's basic needs. Bakari has operated a boda boda (motorcycle) business; he has operated at a nearby market on a daily basis for the past two years. He also owns rental houses and a retail shop which contributes to his other sources of income.

With the Kshs 40,000 he wants to service his motorcycle and to add wheat flour and paraffin to his retail shop for sale. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve his business.

loans.use: To service his motorcycle and buy wheat flour and paraffin to sell

loans.name: Eva

texts.en:
Eva K. lives in the Kisaasi neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has three children, all of whom are in school.  Eva has a business which sells clothes. She has been in this business for 10 years, and she works seven days a week. Eva sells her products in a shop, by means of retail.    

Eva has requested a loan of 600,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bales of new clothes. The main business challenges for Eva include seasonality and the ever-increasing price of clothes. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to become a wholesaler. Eva lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity and to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees, medication and paying utility bills.

loans.use: To buy more bales of new clothes

loans.name: Eric

texts.en:
Eric is a married man with two children, both of whom attend school. They own a house that has piped water but no electricity. He has operated a charcoal selling business for the past two years, selling in a shop to local residents. 

Eric dreams of establishing a retail shop business in the future. With the Kshs 20,000, he wants to purchase 20 sacks of charcoal for sale. Eric decided to join Yehu to gain knowledge on business ideas.

loans.use: To purchase 20 sacks of charcoal for sale

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace N. lives in the Busega neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has four children, all of whom are in school.  She also takes care of an additional family member (her sister’s daughter). Grace has a business of selling clothes. She has been in this business for 10 years, and she works seven days a week. Grace sells her products at the market, by means of retail.    

Grace has requested a loan of 500,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bales of second-hand clothes. She also generates additional income through selling paint for houses. The main business challenges for Grace include seasonality and the ever-increasing price of clothes. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to become a wholesaler. Grace lives in a home that she owns; she doesn't have access to electricity but has access to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees, medication and paying utility bills.

loans.use: To buy more bales of second-hand clothes

loans.name: Thorgom

texts.en:
Thorgom B. is from the village of Mayisyan in the Shirak region of Armenia. He is married with three children – two daughters (20 and 23 years old) and a 14-year-old son. He has a university degree and has worked as a teacher. For the past 15 years he has worked as a farmer. He considers himself a hard-working responsible person. With the food produced on his land, he helps his married daughter with produce.  

He is looking for a loan to purchase seed potatoes, fertilizer and fuel. He expects this business investment to increase the family income by 30 percent. He wishes for his youngest daughter to graduate from university and continue her education. Thorgom enjoys the fresh air of Mayisyan and living close to his relatives.

loans.use: To purchase seed potatoes, fertilizer and fuel

loans.name: Gagik

texts.en:
Gagik B. is from the village of Hacik in the Shirak region of Armenia. He is the proud father of four children – three daughters (24, 28 and 29 years old) and a 16-year-old son. Gagik and his wife have been working on the family farm for over 20 years. He is content with his work and has gained the respect of his fellow villagers. Two of his daughters are married and Gagik helps them with produce grown on the family farm. 

He would like a loan to purchase animal feed. According to Gagik’s plan this investment will increase the family income by 10 percent. As his daughters have completed their education, Gagik also wishes for his son to attend college.

loans.use: To purchase animal feed

loans.name: Rima

texts.en: Rima G. lives in the Shirak region of Armenia in the village of Gharibjanyan. She is a widow with two sons (37 and 39 years old). She has a positive opinion of the services of microfinance institutions. For the past 20 years she has been working as a farmer. Rima has responsibly sustained her business over the years. She is looking for a loan to purchase fertilizer and fuel. With this loan she expects her income to increase by 20 percent. Growing her business will be a valuable asset to her sons' families. She is satisfied with her life in Gharibjanyan surrounded by family and friends.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and fuel

loans.name: Anthony

texts.en:
Anthony is a married man with two children, both of whom attend school. For the past three years, he has operated a grocery business, selling as retail to his neighbours and passersby. He sells green vegetables, potatoes, tomatoes and onions which are consumed on a daily basis at home. 

Anthony dreams of establishing a food vending business in the future. With the loan he is requesting he wants to purchase sacks of dry fish and vegetables for sale. He decided to join Yehu to access loans and to gain knowledge about business.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of dry fish and vegetables for sale

loans.name: Gharib

texts.en:
Gharib G. lives in the Shirak region of Armenia in the village of Banjamin. He is married and was unable to finish high school. He has three children – a 23-year-old daughter and two sons (18 and 21). Both Gharib and his wife have been working on the family farm for 25 years. He also helps his relatives with produce grown on the farm. 

He would like a loan to purchase seed potatoes and fertilizer. According to his business plan this investment will increase the family income by 20 percent. His dream is to see all his children happily married. He particularly is looking forward to being a grandfather. He likes living in Banjamin, the village where he was born, surrounded by good friends and his extended family.

loans.use: To purchase seed potatoes and fertilizer

loans.name: Hassan

texts.en:
Hassan is married with four children; two attend school while two are still too young for school. He has operated a restaurant business for the past three months, selling to his neighbours. He not only operates a restaurant business but also a retail shop which increases his monthly profit to meet his family demands. 

With the loan he is requesting he wants to purchase foodstuffs, wheat flour, maize flour, rice, beans and cooking fat oil. Hassan decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: To purchase foodstuffs, wheat flour, maize flour, rice, beans and cooking fat oil

loans.name: Varditer

texts.en: Varditer I. lives in the village of Erazgavors in the Shirak region of Armenia. She is blessed with a loving husband and three beautiful daughters (17, 21 and 23). She has been pleasantly pleased working with microfinance loans. Due to an illness she had to slaughter four of her pigs. Varditer would like a loan to purchase pigs and a bull. This investment will bring back the income level of the family. She dreams of seeing her daughters find their soulmates and live happy lives. Living in Erazgavors requires a lot of hard work but Varditer is satisfied and enjoys the support of her friends and relatives.

loans.use: To purchase livestock

loans.name: Ravshan

texts.en:
A. Ravshan lives in Instaravshan, Tajikistan. He has four minor children. His wife helps him in business. He is engaged in the cultivation of agricultural products such as wheat and potatoes and also cattle breeding. Ravshan has worked for more than five years in his business, earning profits and purchasing cattle. He would like to get a loan of US$2000 for purchasing cattle, promising to repay on time. Thanks in advance IMON and KIVA he says!

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Teymur

texts.en:
Teymur A. is a 28-year-old man. He is married and the father of two daughters - aged two and four. Teymur lives in the Bilasuvar region. He grew up in a working peasantry family. Cattle-breeding business is very agreeable to him, because he knows very well how to breed animals from his childhood. He breeds cattle and has been in this business for 10 years. 

He took out the loan to buy calves. This is his first loan with AqroInvest and Kiva. With the help of this loan of 1000 AZN, Teymur will buy two more cows for his husbandry. Teymur's goal is to increase his products and thereby increase his household income.

loans.use: To buy two cows

loans.name: Fenya

texts.en: Fenya M. lives in the village of Azatan in the Shirak region of Armenia. She has been a farmer for over 20 years. Even though it is difficult, Fenya enjoys the work. With the help of her husband she has also been able to raise three children – a 13-year-old daughter and two sons (6 and 12 years old).  In order to grow the family business she would like a loan to purchase seed potatoes and fertilizers. She expects the family income to increase by 20 percent. She has a simple dream – for her children to live happy lives.

loans.use: To purchase seed potatoes and fertilizers

loans.name: Maneno

texts.en:
Maneno is married to a housewife. They have one child who is still too young for school. They live in a house that they own which has electricity and piped water. His greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

Maneno has operated a boda boda (motorcycle) business for the past two years. In addition, he sells coconuts as his other source of business which adds additional income. He faces the challenge of transporting clients during the rainy season. 

Maneno decided to join Yehu because of affordable sustainable financial services. With the loan he is requesting he wants to purchase sacks of charcoal for resale.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of charcoal for resale

loans.name: Shokhrukh

texts.en:
Shokhrukh lives in Istaravshan, Tajikistan. He helps his father in the cultivation of onions, melons and wheat. He is also engaged together with his father in an animal husbandry business. He is young, energetic and diligent. In the future he wants to expand his business with his fascination in the crops area. He likes micro-lending organization IMON because repeat clients have reduced interest rates and commission. Shokhrukh would like to get a loan of 12000 Somoni for purchasing onion and melon seeds, and mineral fertilizers which will help him expand his business.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase onion and melon seeds, and mineral fertilizers

loans.name: Varinka

texts.en: Farming is the main way of life in Pokr Sepasar, Armenia.  Most of the inhabitants were born there and try as best as they can to raise families.  Varinka Minisyan was also born in Pokr Sepasar and has been faming the land for 20 years.  She and her husband have been blessed with five children – three daughters (22, 23 and 24 years old) and two sons (10-year-old twins). Varinka would like to grow the business with a loan to purchase feed and livestock. She expects the family income to grow by 25 percent with the investment.  By expanding her business the family wants to continue their life in Pokr Sepasar.

loans.use: To purchase feed and livestock

loans.name: Kahramon

texts.en: S. Kahramon is a very responsible and optimistic person. He has three children and a wife who he has to support. His father is not working - only S. works in the family and is responsible for feeding them. Kahramon began his working life in the catering field. His mother baked pies at home and he sold them in order to feed his family. Saving money, he began his business and got married. He has been in the clothing sales business for six years. Kahramon is currently faced with many problems because as his children grow up, accordingly their expenses are growing too. He would like to get a loan of 11,000 Somoni to buy a place for his business. The only way to get out of this difficulty is to succeed in business, so we hope that his capabilities, along with the services provided by IMON International will help him improve the business. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes and a civilization that dates back to the 4th century BC. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the USSR, further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: to buy a business premises

loans.name: Koryun

texts.en:
Koryun P. lives in the village of Arapy, in the Shirak region of Armenia. Koryun and his wife are the proud parents of two children – a twenty three year old son and a twenty four year old daughter.  Koryun was trained as an economist, but due to economic conditions, he specializes in farming.  

Over the past twenty four years he has built the family business and provided for his family.  Koryun also helps his less fortunate friends and relatives with produce grown on the family farm.   He would like a loan to purchase a tractor.  According to his plan, this investment will increase the family income by fifteen percent.  He dreams to purchase additional land to expand the family business for his children’s future.

loans.use: to purchase farm equipment (tractor)

loans.name: Halim

texts.en:
Halim U. lives in Istaravshan. He is married and the father of two children. He has worked very hard in several different positions, including: cook, master, and artisan. 

After saving some money, Halim began to sell paint and construction materials. Halim has been in this business for 7 years. He wants to expand the business and continue selling construction materials. He would like a loan for 11000 Somoni to purchase additional material, which helps him expand his business. Please support Halim in his continuous efforts to provide for the wellbeing of his family.  
 
More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase construction material

loans.name: Knarik

texts.en:
Knarik S. was born in the village of Pokr Sepasar, which is located in the Shirak region of Armenia.  Living her whole life in Pokr Sepasar, Knarik graduated from high school and married her soul mate.  They have four wonderful sons (twenty one, twenty four, twenty five and twenty seven).  

For the past fifteen years Knarik has run her own farming business.  She also provides produce to her sons’ new families.  Knarik is a hard worker and is planning to expand her business.  She would like a loan to purchase feed and livestock.  She expects her investment will increase the family income by twenty percent.  She is pleased with microfinance services and looks forward to the future.

loans.use: To purchase feed and livestock

loans.name: Roza

texts.en:
Roza S., who lives in the village of Arpy in the Shirak region of Armenia, is married and has three children – a 36-year-old daughter and two sons, aged 35 and 30. Roza, with a high school education and 27 years of experience as a farmer, is requesting a loan to purchase seed and a cow. With this investment in her business, she expects the family income to increase by 20 percent.

Proud of being a farmer and working the land, Roza will be providing security for her children and their family’s future by growing her business.

loans.use: to purchase seed and livestock

loans.name: Sarana

texts.en:
Sarana A. is a loving mother with a great desire to get ahead in life. Her great spirit, strong will and hard work have allowed her to improve the quality of her life and life of her family.  

Sarana is an internally displaced woman who suffered and lost everything in 1993 during the war. She had to create everything from nothing in a new place and new land. After she was dislocated to Bilasuvar city (her present place of living) she decided to continue the work of her life, which is raising sheep and cattle. 

For the past 30 years, this persevering woman has been working very hard at raising and selling sheep and lambs, and with the income she generates she provides a better quality of life for her beloved daughter, who is her greatest joy. 

Sarana asks for a loan of 1,000 AZN  in order to buy more young sheep to sell later when they are fully grown. With this investment she will be able to substantially grow her earnings and improve her quality of life.

loans.use: to purchase 12 sheep

loans.name: Arasaty Group

texts.es:
Arasaty se denomina el excelente grupo de mujeres conformado en la ciudad de Itá, gracias a que la actual Directora General la Sra. Maria G., quien se dedica a la venta de ropas, contactó con la asesora en una reunión semanal que la misma tenía en la zona, para informarse de la forma de trabajo que tiene el Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras, una vez asesorada acerca del Programa logró juntar a 13 mujeres quienes se encuentran trabajando muy a gusto ya en el 3er. ciclo, en forma conjunta y solidaria.
La sra. Maria vende ropas por su ciudad desde hace varios años, es un medio por el cual obtiene su ingreso de manera mensual, pudiendo mantener a su familia económicamente, pero debido a que se aproxima la época de otoño-invierno desea poder abastecerse de ropas de dicha temporada, por ello solicita el crédito, esperando contar con el apoyo de Kiva, como siempre.
texts.en:
Arasaty is the name of the excellent group of women in the city of Itá. The present general director named Maria G., who sells clothing, contacted a counselor in a weekly meeting she had in the area to find out about the type of work the Mujeres Emprendedoras [Enterprising Women] Committee has. Once she was counseled about the program, she was able to get 13 women together who are happily in their 3rd cycle now, working together and supportively. 

Maria has sold clothes in her city for several years. That is the way she makes her monthly income and is able to support her family financially. Due to the fact that the Fall-Winter seasons are coming, she wants to get supplied with clothing for those seasons. That is why she is asking for a loan, hoping to count on Kiva's support, as always.

loans.use: to buy lingerie and winter clothing

loans.name: Mwanamisi

texts.en:
Mwanamisi T. is a married woman with four children, all of whom attend school. Her husband is a fisherman and he contributes to the provision of family basic needs from his earnings. They own a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees. 

Mwanamisi has operated a fresh water selling business for the past year, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality, especially during the hot, dry season when availability of water is low. She dreams of expanding her business and living a comfortable life in the future.

 She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business. With the KES 10,000 she wants to purchase a tank to reserve more water.

loans.use: to purchase a tank to reserve more water.

loans.name: Sop Serigne Cheikh Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité SOP SERIGNE CHEIKH est une ensemble de 15 femmes qui soucieuses du développement de leur terroir ont adhéré au Banc Villageois de KEUR MBAR pour y bénéficier de prêt. Elles sont toutes du même village et sont unies par des liens de solidarité et de parenté. Elles font en général de l'embouche et du petit commerce. 

Madame KHOTE N. (tout à fait à gauche de la photo avec une écharpe blanche) est responsable du groupe. Elle est âgée de 59 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de 03 enfants. Elle a aussi la charge de 04 autres enfants qui lui sont confiés par des parents. 

Elle fait de l'embouche ovine. Elle achète des mouton qu'elle engraisse pendant au moins quatre mois pour les revendre dans les marchés hebdomadaires de sa localité. 

Avec son nouveau crédit elle va financer son projet d'embouche ovine en achetant cinq (5) moutons 

Son objectif est de participer à la prise en charge des dépenses quotidiennes de la famille, tout en renforçant son niveau d'épargne.
texts.en: The SOP SERIGNE SHEIKH solidarity group is composed of 15 women who,concerned about development of their land, joined the KEUR MBAR Banc Villageois in order to receive a loan. They are all from the same village and are united by community and kinship ties. In general, they fatten livestock and operate small businesses. Mrs  Khota N. (on the far left of the photo with a white scarf) is the leader of the group. She is 59 years old, married and the mother of 3 children. She is also responsible for 4 other children whose parents entrusted them to her care. She fattens sheep. She buys sheep that she fattens for at least four months and then sells them in her town's weekly markets.  With her new loan, she will finance her sheep-fattening project and buy five sheep. Her goal is to contribute financially to the support of her family while increasing her level of savings.

loans.use: To buy five sheep to fatten

loans.name: Mehriban

texts.en:
Mehriban A. is 47, an enterprising woman, always happy to do good work. When she was young, she had the goal of self-improvement. 

For about seven years she has been breeding cattle. Her elder son actively helps her to graze cows. This allows her to support her three children who are her reason for being. She has raised them alone since she is a widow. Mehriban's parents also live with them. 

Mehriban wants to increase her capital to buy new animals so she can keep supporting the family. She needs a loan to purchase two baby cows.

loans.use: to purchase two calves

loans.name: Mgeni

texts.en:
Mgeni K. is married with two children who attend school. They own a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees. 

She has operated an open air food market for the past two years, selling to her neighbors and to nearby school children. 

Mgeni decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve her business.

With the KES 15,000 she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, beans and cooking oil. She dreams of being self reliant in the future.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of wheat flour, beans and cooking oil

loans.name: Angela

texts.es:
La Sra. Angela de 63 años de edad se dedica a la venta de ropa y artículos de mercería hace 21 años, vive en la compañía de Paranambu de la ciudad de Itá, es madre de soltera de 6 hijos, ella tiene su negocio en su domicilio, en el cual surte a sus vecinos y a clientes ocasionales de diversos insumos de primera necesidad para el hogar, ropas y artículos de mercería.
El crédito que solicita es para la compra de dichos insumos los cuales traerá de Clorinda en cantidad ya que conseguirá a mejor precio y al venderlos conseguirá un margen mayor de ganancia.
Desde ya agradece a la Fundación Paraguaya por la oportunidad que le brinda.
texts.en:
Sra. Angela, 63 years old, has been selling clothing and sewing supplies for 21 years. She lives in the municipality of Paranambu in the city of Itá. She is a single mother of 6 children. She has a business in her home in which she sells to her neighbors and other clients supplies for home, clothing and sewing. 

The loan that she is requesting is for the sale of said supplies that she will buy in bulk from from Clorinda at the best price and sell them in her business in order to make a profit. 

She is grateful to Fundación Paraguaya for the opportunity that they are giving her.

loans.use: to buy clothing and supplies for home and sewing.

loans.name: Kevin

texts.en:
Kevin R. M. is 27 years old and married. His wife runs a green grocery store and they have two children, ages 3 and 1,  to whom they hope to give good education to the university level. 

Kevin's business is located at a market at Nyalenda in Kisumu. Kisumu is the region of Kenya that harbors Lake Victoria and is well known as the lake basin. 

He owns a butcher shop known by the name Forks Choma/Butchery in which he sells meat to the local people. He has been in this business for three years now. He says that this business is profitable and the major challenge he has is financial constraints. However, he works hard from early morning to late evening to keep his business doing well. 

He is using his loan of KES 20,000 to buy a freezer to keep the meat fresh to increase profits as well as meet his customers' needs. He hopes to open many more butcheries in future. He describes himself as a risk taker.

loans.use: to buy a freezer

loans.name: Amancio

texts.es:
El Sr. Amancio de 57 años de edad, vive en el Barrio Sportivo de la ciudad de Itá, se dedica a la venta de bebida en su domicilio y se halla trabajando también en conjunto con sus hermanos en una distribuidora de bebidas.
El es padre de familia de 4 hijos, quien con su esfuerzo desempeñado día a día va superando los problemas que se le presenta en la vida.
El crédito que está solicitando es para la compra de bebidas (jugos, vinos, wodka, cervezas, freeze, gaseosas) y también de diversos insumos de primera necesidad para el hogar, ya que la necesidad de los vecinos de contar con un almacén más cercano lo lleva a esta decisión acertosa para la venta de esos insumos.
texts.en:
Mr. Amancio is 57 years old and lives in the Barrio Sportivo in the city of Itá. He works selling drinks from his house and he works with his siblings for a drink distributor.
He is the father of 4 children who, with his continued strength, day to day go on overcoming the problems life presents them.
The loan he is requesting is to buy drinks (juices, wines, vodka, beers, freeze, sodas) and also a variety of basic necessities for the house. Because his neighbors need a store nearer to them, he has decided to sell these items.

loans.use: to buy drinks (juices, wines, vodka, beers, freeze, sodas)

loans.name: Satkynbu

texts.en:
Satkynbu D.  is 43, married, and has five children. In 1994, in order to support her family, she began her cattle breeding business. Currently, she has 1 cow, 20 sheep, 50 hens and 70 turkeys at her farm. Satkynbu’s family is also engaged in cultivating land with potatoes and perennial herbs. With the revenues from these activities, Satkynbu managed to give a good education to her children. Now, Satkynbu plans to use this loan of 100,000 KGS to purchase 20 sheep. With the revenues, she plans to build a barn for her cattle. In the future, Satkynbu plans to broaden her business activities. 

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase sheep

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a fridge to store natural juice for sale.

loans.name: Faustina

texts.en:
Faustina, a married woman without children, owns a house that has electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family. Faustina has operated a poultry business for the past two months, selling her chickens to restaurant operators in the market. She also operates a cosmetics shop, a business that helps support the family's basic needs.

Having decided to join Yehu to access loans to get financial assistance, she is requesting Kshs 15,000 to purchase chicken feed.

loans.use: to purchase chicken feed.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase two dairy cows

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy leather, threads, paints, fabrics, rope and sponge filler

loans.name: Binti

texts.en:
Binti is a married woman with two children. One attends school while the other is still young for school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity and piped water. 

Binti has operated a green grocery business for the past six years, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby.

In addition she also operates a café business that is her other source of livelihood. Binti faces a major challenge of delayed payments by those who purchase goods on credit. She dreams of establishing a cereal shop in the future. 

Binti decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business in the future. With the KES 80,000 she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour and cooking oil and purchase building stones and cement to renovate her stall.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of wheat flour and cooking oil and to purchase building stones and cement to renovate her stall

loans.name: Benon

texts.en:
Benon lives in Kyenjojo, Uganda.

He deals in the sale of maize and has been in this business for the last five years.

However, he has a challenge of labor and transport. 

He dreams of educating his children and becoming a large-scale maize dealer.

Benon needs the loan to buy maize for sale.

loans.use: to buy maize to resell

loans.name: La Esperanza Group

texts.es:
La Esperanza se denomina el excelente grupo de mujeres conformado en la ciudad de Ita, gracias a que la actual Directora General la Sra. Jacinta G., quien se dedica a la venta de comida, contactó con la asesora en una reunión semanal que la misma tenía en la zona, para informarse de la forma de trabajo que tiene el Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras, ahora son 15 mujeres que se encuentran trabajando muy a gusto ya en el 3° ciclo.
La sra. Jacinta solicita el préstamo de los inversionistas mediante Kiva, para la compra de los insumos necesarios para preparar comidas (panificados, carnes, condimentos, cereales, fideos, arroz, etc.), pues solo proveyéndose de comestibles podrá satisfacer las necesidades de sus clientes y ayudar a su familia y a ella misma a superar la pobreza en la que viven.
texts.en:
This superb group of women is called 'La Esperanza' (Hope).  The group was formed in the city of Ita by the current Director General, Jacinta González, whose business is selling meals.  She contacted the advisor during a weekly meeting that she had in the area to find out how the 'Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras' (Committee of Enterprising Women) works.  The group now has 15 female members who are very happily working on their third loan cycle.  

Jacinta is requesting this loan through Kiva to buy the supplies she needs to prepare her meals (baked goods, meat, condiments, cereals, noodles, rice, etc.) as these food products are necessary in order to meet her customers' needs and to help herself and her family climb out of the poverty in which they currently live.

loans.use: to buy supplies for preparing meals (baked goods, condiments, cereals, noodles, rice and meat)

loans.name: Moses

texts.en:
Moses is a 42-year-old married man with six children. He lives in a permanent house in the district of Kyenjojo, Uganda. 

He has a retail shop and he desires to become a wholesale trader. 

Moses intends to use the loan to buy sugar and maize flour for resale.

loans.use: to buy sugar and maize flour for resale

loans.name: Zena

texts.en:
Zena S. is a married woman with three school-going children. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees. 

For the past three years, she has operated a business selling lesos (Khangas), a traditional African shawl or wrap. She sells from home to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a challenge in the high cost of transportation in her business. She dreams of expanding her business and becoming self-reliant in the future.

Zena decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business. With the KES 20,000 she wants to purchase bundles of lesos (Khangas) for resale.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of lesos (Khangas) for resale

loans.name: Mwatime

texts.en:
Mwatime is a married woman with five children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. She has operated a bread baking business for the past two years, selling from home to her neighbours and nearby school children.

Mwatime faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. With the 15,000 KES loan, she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour and sugar. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To  purchase wheat flour and sugar

loans.name: Leo
